content.title: Immune Thrombocytopenia (ITP)
content.summary: Immune thrombocytopenia (ITP, formerly idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia due to antibody-mediated platelet destruction and impaired platelet production. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. Treatment aims to prevent bleeding rather than normalize platelet count, with corticosteroids as first-line therapy and IVIG for urgent situations.
key_points: Diagnosis of exclusion: isolated thrombocytopenia (<100 × 10⁹/L) without other cause
Primary ITP (no identifiable cause) vs Secondary ITP (SLE, HIV, HCV, drugs)
Mechanism: autoantibodies against platelet glycoproteins (GPIIb/IIIa, GPIb/IX)
Treatment goal: prevent bleeding, not normalize platelet count
First-line: Corticosteroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg or dexamethasone 40 mg × 4 days)
Urgent treatment: IVIG (1 g/kg × 1-2 days) for rapid platelet increase
content.statement: Immune thrombocytopenia is an acquired autoimmune disorder causing isolated thrombocytopenia through antibody-mediated platelet destruction and impaired megakaryopoiesis, managed with corticosteroids as first-line therapy with the goal of preventing bleeding rather than achieving a normal platelet count.

explanation.intuition: In ITP, the immune system mistakenly tags platelets as foreign and destroys them. Antibodies coat platelets, which are then eaten by macrophages in the spleen. At the same time, these antibodies suppress platelet production. The result: very low platelets but normal bone marrow trying (and failing) to compensate.
explanation.key_insight: ITP is a diagnosis of EXCLUSION - you must rule out other causes of thrombocytopenia first. The treatment goal is preventing bleeding, not achieving a 'normal' platelet count. Many patients do fine with platelets of 30-50 without treatment.
explanation.technical_details: Antiplatelet antibodies target GPIIb/IIIa (most common) or GPIb/IX. Fc-receptor mediated phagocytosis occurs primarily in the spleen. TPO-RAs (romiplostim, eltrombopag) work by stimulating megakaryopoiesis to overcome destruction. Rituximab depletes B-cells producing autoantibodies.

definitions_glossary.immune_thrombocytopenia: Autoimmune disorder causing isolated thrombocytopenia via platelet destruction
definitions_glossary.secondary_ITP: ITP associated with underlying disorder (SLE, HIV, HCV, drugs)
definitions_glossary.GPIIb_IIIa: Platelet glycoprotein; most common target of antiplatelet antibodies in ITP
definitions_glossary.corticosteroids: First-line treatment; reduce antibody production and phagocytosis
definitions_glossary.IVIG: Intravenous immunoglobulin; saturates Fc receptors to reduce platelet destruction
definitions_glossary.romiplostim: TPO-RA administered subcutaneously weekly; stimulates platelet production
definitions_glossary.eltrombopag: Oral TPO-RA; also stimulates platelet production
definitions_glossary.rituximab: Anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody; depletes B-cells producing autoantibodies
definitions_glossary.splenectomy: Removes major site of platelet destruction; second-line durable option
definitions_glossary.fostamatinib: Spleen tyrosine kinase (SYK) inhibitor; blocks phagocytosis

pathophysiology.mechanism: Autoantibodies against platelet surface glycoproteins → Fc receptor-mediated phagocytosis in spleen/liver → thrombocytopenia. Also impaired megakaryopoiesis from antibodies against megakaryocytes.

primary_vs_secondary.primary: No identifiable underlying cause; ~80% of cases

bleeding_patterns.mucocutaneous: Petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, gum bleeding, menorrhagia
bleeding_patterns.risk_factors: Platelets <20, older age, concurrent anticoagulation, recent trauma

clinical_manifestations.when_to_suspect: Isolated thrombocytopenia in an otherwise healthy individual, especially young women

diagnostic_criteria.definition: Platelet count <100 × 10⁹/L in absence of other causes

workup.CBC: Isolated thrombocytopenia; normal WBC and hemoglobin (unless bleeding)
workup.peripheral_smear: Normal platelet morphology (may be large); no schistocytes, no blasts
workup.bone_marrow: NOT routinely required; consider if atypical features or before splenectomy

NOT_required_for_diagnosis: Bone marrow biopsy in typical cases

differential_diagnosis: Bone marrow failure (aplastic anemia, MDS, leukemia)

treatment_thresholds.bleeding: Treat if any clinically significant bleeding
treatment_thresholds.procedure: Platelets >50 for most; >80-100 for major surgery

corticosteroids.limitations: Relapse common after steroid taper; long-term use has significant toxicity

IVIG.mechanism: Saturates Fc receptors; rapid effect within 1-3 days

urgent_bleeding.platelet_transfusion: Give if life-threatening bleeding; effect is brief
urgent_bleeding.anti_D_immunoglobulin: Alternative to IVIG in Rh+ non-splenectomized patients

TPO_receptor_agonists.considerations: Require ongoing treatment; risk of thrombosis, bone marrow fibrosis

splenectomy.mechanism: Removes major site of platelet destruction
splenectomy.considerations: Requires vaccination (encapsulated organisms); lifelong infection risk

definition.@value: An acquired autoimmune disorder characterized by isolated thrombocytopenia due to antibody-mediated platelet destruction and impaired platelet production, diagnosed by exclusion of other causes

scopeNote.@value: Common cause of isolated thrombocytopenia requiring exclusion of secondary causes

learning_objectives: Recognize ITP as a diagnosis of exclusion
Apply appropriate first-line treatment with corticosteroids
Identify when to use IVIG for urgent platelet increase
Understand second-line options including TPO-RAs and rituximab
clinical_pearls: ITP is a diagnosis of EXCLUSION - always rule out other causes
Treatment goal is preventing bleeding, not normalizing platelet count
Platelets 30-50 without bleeding often don't need treatment
IVIG works fast (1-3 days) but temporary; use for urgent situations
Check for pseudothrombocytopenia (EDTA artifact) before diagnosing
common_misconceptions: All low platelet counts need treatment - asymptomatic ITP often observed
Bone marrow biopsy required for diagnosis - not in typical cases
Platelet transfusion works well in ITP - effect is very brief due to destruction
